questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with h/o easy fatigability, decreased interest in day-to-day activities, and dizziness. On examination he is pale and his weight is 50kgs. His Hb was found to be 7g/dl (normal 14-16g/dl), MCV -95fL, MCH -23pg/cell, serum iron 40μg/dl, serum ferritin 9ng/mL and peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia. A diagnosis of iron deficiency anemia is made. Which of the following is true regarding iron replacement therapy in iron deficiency anemia?

options.label: A
options.text: Oral iron is to be given till the Hematocrit normalizes and should be discontinued afterward because of gastric side effects

options.label: B
options.text: Before giving parenteral iron dilute the dose and give it to check for anaphylaxis

options.label: C
options.text: 50% of the iron given is absorbed in 325 mg of ferrous sulfate tablets

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the adverse effects of oral iron always give parenteral iron for treatment

questions.correct_answer: B. Before giving parenteral iron dilute the dose and give it to check for anaphylaxis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Before giving parenteral iron dilute the dose and give it to check for anaphylaxis

Highyeild:

Treatment of Acute iron poisoning Stomach wash with 1% NaHCO, to render it insoluble and remove undissolved iron tablets Desferrioxamine Mesylate 5 to 10 g in 100 mL isotonic saline or calcium sodium edetate 35 to 40 mg/Kg to retard the absorption from GIT Early replacement of fluids and electrolytes, correction of metabolic acidosis and hypotension by using RL and vasopressors v desferrioxamine infusion Diazepam and other anticonvulsants if epileptic Iron replacement therapy note: Iron preparations are known to cause allergic reactions So, Before giving parenteral iron dilute the dose and give it to check for anaphylaxis Oral iron to be given till the Hematocrit normalizes and should be continued afterward for another 3 months and replenish iron stores If gastric side effects occur shift to parenteral iron Before giving parenteral iron dilute the dose and give it to check for anaphylaxis 20% of the iron given is absorbed in 325 mg of ferrous sulfate tablets Oral iron therapy is best as it is easier for patients to take on their own but if adverse effects occur to oral iron then give parenteral iron for treatment

questions.text: A 5-year-old child comes to emergency swallowing 10 Tablets of iron formulations. The child had the following manifestations like vomiting, abdominal pain, haematemesis, diarrhea, lethargy Necrotizing gastroenteritis, shock, and metabolic acidosis. Which one of the following drugs would be useful in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deferoxamine

Highyeild:

In the evaluation of a child thought to have ingested iron a color test for iron in the gastric contents and determination of the concentration of iron in plasma can be performed if the concentration of iron in plasma is less than 63 μmol(3.5 mg/l), the child is not in immediate danger. Vomiting should be induced when there is iron in the stomach x-ray should be taken to evaluate the number of pills remaining in the small bowel (iron tablets are radiopaque). when the plasma concentration of iron is greater than the total iron-binding capacity (63 μmol; 3.5 mg/l), deferoxamine should be administered, which is an iv iron chelating agent

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be required by a 5-year-old boy with chronic renal insufficiency?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Erythropoietin

Highyeild:

Erythropoietin (EPO) is a sialoglycoprotein hormone Anemia and hypoxia are sensed by kidney cells and induce rapid secretion of EPO, which acts on erythroid marrow and: Stimulates proliferation of colony-forming cells of the erythroid series. Induces hemoglobin formation and erythroblast maturation. Releases reticulocytes in circulation. Patients with chronic renal insufficiency often require exogenous erythropoietin to avoid chronic anemia

questions.text: Twenty months after finishing her chemotherapy, the woman had a relapse of breast cancer. The cancer was now unresponsive to standard doses of chemotherapy. The decision was made to treat the patient with high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be used to mobilize the peripheral blood stem cells needed for the patient's autologous stem cell transplantation?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Filgrastim (G-CSF)

Highyeild:

The success of transplantation with peripheral blood stem cells depends on the infusion of adequate numbers of hematopoietic stem cells. Administration of G-CSF to the donor (in the case of autologous transplantation, the patient who also will be the recipient of the transplantation) greatly increases the number of hematopoietic stem cells harvested from the donor's blood and available for the transplantation procedure.
